{{Infobox Person | name = Laura Fair | image = Laura Fair.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1837 | birth_place = [[Holly Springs, Mississippi|Holly Springs]] | death_date = 1919 | death_place = [[San Francisco]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = murdering her lover | education = | employer = | occupation = | spouse = 1.?
2.?
William D. Fair | partner = [[Alexander P. Crittenden]] | children = one | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = }} '''Laura D. Fair''' (1837–1919) was an American murderer whose death sentence was overturned. == Early life == Laura Fair was born in [[Holly Springs, Mississippi|Holly Springs]], [[Mississippi]] in 1837. She married her first husband, an alcohol dealer from [[New Orleans]], in 1853 at 16 years old. He died in 1854 and she started school at the Convent of Visitation to become a teacher. Fair left school in a year to re-marry but shortly abandoned him to join her mother operating a boarding house in [[San Francisco]]. Fair met her third husband, Attorney William D. Fair after moving to [[Shasta, California|Shasta]], [[California]]. Three years later, the couple separated and Fair committed suicide leaving Laura to support herself, young daughter, and mother.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QrNvJpE0Q3YC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22laura+fair%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi9-PjM5OzPAhUJ0IMKHb4YBVw4ChDoAQgbMAA#v=onepage&q=%22laura%20fair%22&f=false|title=Gold Diggers & Silver Miners: Prostitution and Social Life on the Comstock Lode|last=Goldman|first=Marion S.|date=1981-01-01|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=0472063324|language=en}} == Murder and trial == In September 1862, Fair opened the Tahoe House in [[Virginia City, Nevada|Virginia City]], [[Nevada]] on South C Street. In 1863, Fair started a relationship with married lawyer [[Alexander P. Crittenden|Alexander Parker Crittenden]].{{Cite web|url=http://origins.osu.edu/review/woman-scorned|title=A Woman Scorned? {{!}} Origins: Current Events in Historical Perspective|website=origins.osu.edu|access-date=2016-10-21}} Initially, he said he was single. Fair eventually learned the truth, and Crittenden promised her he would divorce his wife, Clara Churchill Jones.{{Cite web|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/clementsmss/umich-wcl-M-2113cri?view=text|title=Crittenden family papers 1837-1907|website=quod.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2016-10-21}} In 1870, Clara took a transcontinental train to the East Coast and back with her two youngest children. Fair learned that Crittenden was to meet his wife in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and aboard a ferry back to San Francisco. On November 3, 1870, Fair caught the same ferry and shot Crittenden in the heart.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/The-case-of-Laura-Fair-San-Francisco-1870-5585715.php|title=The case of Laura Fair, San Francisco 1870|newspaper=SFGate|access-date=2016-10-21}}{{Cite web|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/c/clementsmss/umich-wcl-M-2113cri?view=text|title=Crittenden family papers 1837-1907|website=quod.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2016-10-21}} In April 1871, Fair faced her first murder trial where she claimed that the shooting was the result of temporary insanity caused by a severely painful menstrual cycle. The prosecution painted her as a fallen woman who lured Crittenden into bed and warned the jury that they had a moral obligation. While in jail, [[Susan B. Anthony]] and [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]] visited Fair to support her. The jury found Fair guilty of murder, and she was sentenced to hang on July 28, 1871.{{Cite web|url=http://www.uncpress.unc.edu/browse/book_detail?title_id=3433|title=UNC Press - The Trials of Laura Fair|last=Hill|first=Copyright 2016 The University of North Carolina at Chapel|website=www.uncpress.unc.edu|access-date=2016-10-21}} Fair’s case was appealed with the support of suffragettes, including [[Emily Pitts Stevens]], founder of the California Woman Suffrage Association. The conviction was overturned on the grounds of prejudice. The press, having supported the initial conviction, were decidedly upset, calling the acquittal a "shameful miscarriage of justice."{{sfn|Public Opinion|1872|p=522}} == Death == Fair died in 1919, at the age of 82, in San Francisco. Her body was buried in an unmarked grave. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{Source-attribution| {{cite book|ref=harv|author=Public Opinion|title=Public Opinion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XrpRDTgJ5RYC&pg=PA522|edition=Public domain|volume=22|year=1872|publisher=Public Opinion|location=London}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fair, Laura}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:People from Holly Springs, Mississippi]] [[Category:American female murderers]] [[Category:American murderers]] [[Category:American female criminals]] [[Category:Overturned convictions in the United States]] [[Category:People from Shasta, California]] [[Category:People acquitted by reason of insanity]]

[[Maria Vladimirovna, Grand Duchess of Russia]] | house = [[Bagrationi dynasty|Bagration]]-[[House of Mukhrani|Mukhrani]] | father = [[George Bagration of Mukhrani|Prince George Bagration of Mukhrani]] | mother = Helena Złotnicka h. Nowina | birth_date = {{Birth date|1914|10|6|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Tbilisi|Tiflis]], [[Caucasus Viceroyalty (1801-1917)|Caucasus Viceroyalty]], [[Russian Empire]] (now [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|5|23|1914|10|6|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] | burial_date = 2 June 2010 | burial_place = [[Grand Ducal Mausoleum]], [[St. Petersburg]] | religion = [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] }} '''Leonida Georgievna Romanova, Grand Duchess of Russia''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Леонида Георгиевна Романова; ''née'' '''Princess Leonida Georgievna Bagration-Mukhraneli''' ([[Georgian language|Georgian]]: ლეონიდა გიორგის ასული ბაგრატიონი-მუხრანელი); {{OldStyleDate|6 October|1914|23 September}} – 23 May 2010) was the consort of [[Grand Duke Vladimir Kirillovich of Russia|Vladimir Kirillovich, Grand Duke of Russia]], a [[Line of succession to the former Russian throne|pretender to the Russian throne]]. She was an active and outspoken advocate of the claims advanced by Vladimir and their daughter, [[Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna of Russia|Maria Vladimirovna]], to be accepted as the legitimate Heads of the [[Romanov]] dynasty and ''[[de jure]]'' sovereigns of the [[Russian Empire]].[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/last-romanov-born-in-russian-empire-dead-at-95/406706.html] "Last Romanov Born In Russian Empire Dead At 95," The Moscow Times, 25 May 2010 ==Early life== [[File:Leonida Bragation.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Princess Leonida.]] [[File:Багратион-Мухранский Георгий Александрович.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Father of Leonida, [[George Bagration of Mukhrani]].]] Born on 6 October 1914, in [[Tiflis]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Russian Empire]] as Princess Leonida [[House of Mukhrani|Bagration of Mukhrani]], she was a daughter of Prince [[George Bagration of Mukhrani]] and his [[Poles|Polish]] wife Helena Sigismundovna, ''née'' Nowina Złotnicka (1886–1979).[http://www.royalark.net/Georgia/mukhran4.htm Royal Ark] She descended [[patrilineality|patrilineally]] from former Kings of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}. Her mother’s family belonged to the untitled [[Szlachta|Polish aristocracy]],''[[The Times]]'', London. "[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article7149792.ece Leonida Georgievna Romanov]", 15 June 2010. although one of Leonida's two lines of descent from Georgia's penultimate king [[Erekle II]] (Heraclius II) is through her mother, a descendant of the king's daughter, Princess Anastasia, who married an [[Eristavi#Eristavi families|Eristavi]] prince{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}. The other ancestral line derives through the marriage of another of the king's daughters, Princess Tamara, to [[House of Mukhrani#Princes of Mukhrani (1512-1801)|Ioane Bagrationi, 18th Prince of Mukhrani]]{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}. The [[Bagrationi dynasty|Bagration]] family's genealogy traces back at least to the [[medieval era]] in [[David Soslan#Consort of Georgia|its male line]] and hundreds of years further back as rulers in the [[Tamar of Georgia#Genealogy|female line]].Eastmond, Antony (1998), ''Royal Imagery in Medieval Georgia'', pp. 135-7. Penn State Press, {{ISBN|0271016280}}. Leonida's grandfather, Prince [[Alexander Bagration of Mukhrani]], was born in 1853 in Georgia's historical capital [[Tbilisi]], then part of the [[Russian Empire]], and was killed by [[Bolshevik]]s at [[Pyatigorsk]] in 1918 during the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian revolution]]. Fearing for their lives, the family took refuge in [[Constantinople]], then spent eight months in Germany before returning to Tbilisi, now capital of the [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic]], to re-claim a portion of property which, as ''[[émigré]]s'' they risked losing to total [[confiscation]]. Although the family made repairs to their home and Leonida would recall her grandfather's insistence that they continue to dine formally on silver plate to retain their sense of propriety, they were eventually deprived of all but two rooms of their old palace and subjected to harassment.''The [[The Daily Telegraph#Website|Telegraph.co.uk]]'', London. "[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/royalty-obituaries/7779624/Grand-Duchess-Leonida-of-Russia.html Grand Duchess Leonida of Russia]", 28 May 2010. Thanks to the intervention of [[Maxim Gorky]], who had enjoyed the patronage of the Bagrations, in 1931 they once again fled the Soviet Union, going into exile in Spain. The family moved to [[France]], where Leonida's grandmother and relations had already settled. ==First marriage== In France, Princess Leonida met Sumner Moore Kirby (1895–1945), a wealthy "[[Pennsylvania Dutch Country|Pennsylvanian Protestant]]". They were married in [[Nice]], France, on 6 November 1934. Sumner Moore Kirby had been born in [[Wilkes Barre]], Pennsylvania, the younger of two sons of Fred Morgan Kirby, a millionaire and business partner of one of the [[F. W. Woolworth Company]] heirs ([[Charles Sumner Woolworth]]) and his wife Jessie Amelie Owen. Leonida was his third wife, he having been married from 1925 to 1931 to Doris Landy Wayland, with whom he had a daughter, Gloria Price Kirby (born 1928). Kirby's second marriage, to Valentine Wagner, lasted from 20 January 1932 to 19 July 1934. Valentine Wagner's mother was born Princess Elisabeth Bagration, a member of the same family as Princess Leonida. Her father was Conrad Wagner. Kirby had no children of this marriage which, like his first and third marriages, was contracted civilly in Nice and dissolved there. Leonida and Sumner Kirby had one daughter, Helen Louise Kirby, born in [[Geneva]], Switzerland, on 26 January 1935. Their marriage was short-lived, they divorced after three years on 18 November 1937. Kirby died in a hospital at Leau, near the [[Buchenwald Concentration Camp]] to which he had been deported from France after being arrested along with other U.S. and British civilians by the [[Vichy regime]] in 1944. As war intensified, Leonida and her daughter relocated to officially neutral [[Spain]]. In 1944, Leonida's brother, [[Irakli Bagration of Mukhrani|Prince Irakli]], also moved to Spain. ==Second marriage== According to her published memoirs, Leonida first met Vladimir Kirillovich at a restaurant in France during World War II. But they did not see each other again for a few years, when both were making extended visits to [[Sanlúcar de Barrameda]], Spain, where their hosts happened to be neighbors. Vladimir was staying with his aunt, the [[Princess Beatrice of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|Infanta Beatrice de Orleans]], first cousin of the murdered [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Tsarina Alexandra]]. On 13 August 1948 Princess Leonida wed for the second time, marrying Vladimir Kirillovich Romanov, who used the pre-revolutionary Russian title [[Grand Duke]], the style ''[[Imperial Highness]]'' and claimed to be, from 1938 to his death, Head of the Russian Imperial House[http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1115.htmlAn Announcement by the Office of the Head of the Russian Imperial House] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725135945/http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1115.htmlAn |date=25 July 2011 }}. Retrieved 19 June 2010. by virtue of being hereditary heir by [[primogeniture]] to the throne of the Romanovs according to the Fundamental Laws of the Russian Empire, as codified in 1906 and in force until overturned by the [[Bolshevik Revolution]] of 1917.[http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1115.html Fundamental State Laws] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808052647/http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1115.html |date=8 August 2014 }}. Retrieved 19 June 2010. In 1783, the [[Treaty of Georgievsk]] was signed through which the Kingdom of Georgia, while retaining its autonomy and its ancient monarchy was placed under the protection of the Russian Empire. In 1801 after the death of [[George XII of Georgia|George XII]], the last King of Georgia, Tsar [[Alexander I of Russia]] in violation of the treaty, annexed the kingdom of Georgia and the Bagration dynasty lost its throne. The Bagrations became a leading family of the Russian nobility, serving in the Tsar's army and at court in [[Saint Petersburg]]. The former ruling branch became extinct in the late 19th century {{citation needed|date=April 2014}}, when it passed its succession rights to the branch to which Grand Duchess Leonida belonged{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}, but this too is disputed. [[Joseph Stalin]]'s mother had been a laundress in the house of the Bagrations. As his [[queen consort|consort]] she used the title Grand Duchess Leonida Georgievna. By him, she had another daughter, [[Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna of Russia|Maria Vladimirovna]], who claims to have succeeded her father upon his death in 1992.[http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/imperialhouse/chipdom/maria.html Website of Grand Duchess Maria] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004200455/http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/imperialhouse/chipdom/maria.html |date=4 October 2008 }} In 1946, Leonida's brother, [[Irakli Bagration of Mukhrani|Prince Irakly]], married King [[Alfonso XIII]]'s niece, [[Prince Ferdinand of Bavaria|Princess Doña María de las Mercedes de Baviera y Borbon]] (1911–1953), obtaining Vladimir's recommendation that the Spanish pretender, [[Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona|Don Juan, Count of Barcelona]], accept the marriage as [[dynasty#Dynasts|dynastic]], which he did not. The Count of Barcelona, then Head of the Royal House of Spain, considered the issue of this marriage to be disqualified from the Spanish succession. The only son of this marriage was sponsored at his baptism by the Count of Barcelona but the latter's refusal to recognize his god-son as a Spanish dynast led to the Bagrations' alienation from the Spanish Royal Family according to [[Guy Stair Sainty]]. In 1948 Vladimir, relying on his own earlier advice on the Bagrations' historically royal status,[http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1117.html 1946 Decree of the Head of the Russian Imperial House] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419142442/http://www.imperialhouse.ru/eng/dynastyhistory/dinzak3/1117.html |date=19 April 2014 }}. Retrieved 19 June 2010. chose to wed Leonida ''dynastically'' in [[Lausanne]], Switzerland. ==Controversy== The Grand Duke's marriage to Leonida Bagration remained controversial; some considered it to be [[morganatic marriage|morganatic]]. Although the princess descended from the [[Bagrationi dynasty]] which had ruled as kings of Georgia since the early Middle Ages, it had been [[deposition (law)|deposed]] and reduced to the status of Russian nobility for more than a century prior to the Russian Revolution in 1917. Leonida belonged to the senior surviving branch of that family {{citation needed|date=April 2014}}, but the last Georgian king from whom she descended in the male line was [[Constantine II of Georgia|Constantine II]] who died in 1505,[[Cyril Toumanoff]], "The Fifteenth-Century Bagratides and the Institution of Collegial Sovereignty in Georgia". Traditio. Volume VII, Fordham University Press, New York 1949–1951, pp. 169–221. although other branches of the family continued to reign in the [[Caucasus]] as late as 1810. Besides, according to the Almanach de Gotha, as per the decision of Emperor Nicholas II made in 1911, the Princess Tatiana Constantinovna of Russia had morganatically wed Prince Konstantin Alexandrovich Bagration-Mukhransky, a member of the [[House of Mukhrani|same branch]] of the House of Bagration into which Princess Leonida would later be born. Because the [[Russian Empire]] did not accord royal rank to the Bagrations at the time of the Russian Revolution, most Romanov [[dynasty#Dynasts|dynasts]] in exile maintained that Leonida's daughter, Maria Vladimirovna, could not succeed to her father's claim to the Russian throne.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Claimant's consort== Leonida accompanied her husband when he made his only visit to Russia in November 1991, following the implosion of the [[Soviet Union]]. She was also at Vladimir's side the following year when he collapsed and died following delivery of a speech in [[Florida]]. She visited her own ancestral land with her nephew [[Jorge de Bagration|Prince George Bagration of Mukhrani]] in 1995 when he first visited Georgia as a royal pretender to that country's [[abolished monarchy]]. But she did not attend the much-publicized 2009 wedding of her grand-nephew, Prince [[David Bagration of Mukhrani]] to Princess [[Ana Bagration-Gruzinsky]], the heiress of King [[George XII of Georgia]], celebrated at the restored [[Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi]]. Nor did she re-locate her home from western Europe to Russia, although she visited the country repeatedly following her husband's funeral and burial in [[Saint Petersburg]]. Wealth inherited by her elder, unmarried daughter Helen Kirby (styled by Vladimir's declaration as "Countess Dvinskaya"), helped Leonida, her second husband and younger daughter maintain homes in the north of France and in Madrid. There, both Maria Vladimirovna, who remains active as the claimant to the throne of the Romanovs in exile, and Maria's only son, [[Grand Duke George Mikhailovich of Russia|Grand Duke George Mikhailovich]] (born in 1981, his father is Maria's ex-husband and distant cousin, [[Prince Franz Wilhelm of Prussia]]), were reared. ==Death== Leonida Georgievna died on 23 May 2010, after her health had rapidly deteriorated. She requested to be buried next to her husband Vladimir Kirillovich in the [[Grand Ducal Mausoleum]], Saint Petersburg. She was the last member of the Romanov family born on the territory of the [[Russian Empire]][https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/7759313/Last-Romanov-born-in-Russian-empire-dies-aged-95.html Last Romanov born in Russian empire dies aged 95] during the monarchy. ==Titles, styles and honours== ===Titles=== *'''23 September 1914 - 13 August 1948:''' ''Her Serene Highness'' Princess Leonida Georgievna Bagration-Moukhransky''Genealogisches Handbuch des Adels, Fürstliche Häuser'' XIV. "Haus Preußen". C.A. Starke Verlag, 1991, pp. 123, 153. {{ISBN|3-7980-0700-4}}. *'''13 August 1948 - 21 April 1992:''' ''Her Imperial Highness'' The Grand Duchess of Russia *'''21 April 1992 - 23 May 2010:''' ''Her Imperial Highness'' The Dowager Grand Duchess of Russia ===Honours=== ====National dynastic honours==== * {{flagicon|Georgia}} [[Bagrationi dynasty|House of Bagrationi]]: Knight Grand Cross of the {{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Biographies|date=February 2015}} {{Orphan|date=January 2011}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Nansen G. Saleri | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|8|9|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Turkey]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Reservoir Engineer
Oil Executive | spouse = Marina Saleri | parents = | children = 2 daughters, 1 son | alma_mater = [[Boğaziçi University]] (then called Robert College, 1970)
[[University of Virginia]] | education = [[Robert Academy]] (1966) | residence = [[Texas]] | awards = [[SPE John Franklin Carll Award]] (2006) }} '''Nansen G. Saleri''' (born 1947) is president and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Quantum Reservoir Impact]]. He specializes in [[reservoir]] management and [[Upstream (petroleum industry)|upstream]] technologies. As former head of Reservoir Management in [[Saudi Aramco]], Saleri was principal driver behind Saudi Aramco’s technological ascendancy in its upstream capabilities, specifically in the area of modern reservoir management, smart technologies, and maximum reservoir contact (MRC)/next-generation [[oil well]]s. ==Early life and education== Nansen G. Saleri was born in [[Turkey]]. He has a twin brother, Washington, D.C. psychiatrist Alen Salerian.[http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/people/the-spectacular-unraveling-of-washingtons-favorite-shrink-starring-alen-salerian/ The Spectacular Unraveling of Washington’s Favorite Shrink | People & Politics | Washingtonian]{{cite news| author =| title =JFK celebrated with a Magnificent Exhibition at the Woman’s National Democratic Club| quote =| newspaper = SwedishScene| date =November 2009| url =http://www.swedishscene.com/2009/11/jfk-celebrated-at-art-opening.html | accessdate =February 5, 2015}}{{cite news| author =Paulina Rojas| title =Family prepares to honor mother’s art| quote =| newspaper =[[The Daily Cougar]]| date = April 15, 2013| url =http://thedailycougar.com/2013/04/15/family-prepares-to-honor-mothers-art/| accessdate =February 5, 2015}} Saleri attended [[Robert Academy]] in Turkey from 1961 to 1966.{{cite news| author =| title = Petroleum Industry Awards Nansen Saleri, RA 66, for Work on Global Reserves (page 10)| quote =Saleri attended [[Robert Academy]] (1961-1966) and then Robert College (1966-1970), where he received his B.S. in Chemical Engineering. In 1970, he married his wife Marina, and the couple headed to the USA where pursued M.S. and PhD degrees at the University of Virginia.| newspaper =Robert College Alumni Magazine| date =2007| url =http://webportal.robcol.k12.tr/Alumni-Development/RC-quarterly/RC%20Quarterly/RCQ031.pdf| accessdate =February 5, 2015}} Saleri holds a M.Sc. and a Ph.D. in [[chemical engineering]] from the [[University of Virginia]] and a B.Sc. from [[Boğaziçi University]] (then called Robert College), also in chemical engineering.{{cite web | url=http://www.qrigroup.com/nansen-saleri | title=Dr. Nansen G. Saleri | QRI Group}}{{cite web |url=http://terra.rice.edu/web/events/peak/Bio_Saleri.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613184610/http://terra.rice.edu/web/events/peak/Bio_Saleri.pdf |archivedate=2010-06-13 |df= }} ==Career== Saleri worked for [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] (1974–1992) and served as Manager of Reservoir Engineering in [[Houston, Texas]]. He is author and principal instructor for Chevron’s Reservoir Management training (1998–2002). He has been involved in world-wide projects ([[Gulf of Mexico]], [[West Texas]], [[Elk Hills]], [[West Africa]], [[Indonesia]], and [[Papua New Guinea]]). He joined Saudi Aramco as a Petroleum Engineer specialist in 1992. Saleri was chief architect of Saudi Aramco's successful reservoir management and water optimization programs, most notably for [[Ghawar]], the world’s largest field. Saleri oversaw the company’s Maximum Sustained Capability (MSC) commitments at 10.8 million barrels per day and strategic planning for its oil and gas assets. He has assumed leadership role in numerous functions, including lead the Best-in-Class Strategic Imperative in Well Optimization, and established the Company’s Reservoir Management Metrics and Chaired the corporate Gas Development Strategy Task Force. He directed reservoir development plans for several major projects, including Hawiyah and Haradh Gas Plants, Shaybah AXL, Haradh Increments II and III, Qatif/Abu-Safah, Nuayyim, AFK, Khurais, among others. Saleri started his own company called Quantum Reservoir Impact (QRI).{{cite news| author =The Big E| title =This week in peak oil| quote =| newspaper =[[Daily Kos]]| date = March 7, 2008| url =http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/03/08/471871/-This-week-in-peak-oil#| accessdate =February 5, 2015}} The company describes itself as a value creation agency designed to help oil companies maximize efficiencies in extracting oil from their reservoirs. They claim to do this through the use of cutting-edge technology and novel practices. Saleri has authored numerous technical papers and has been a featured speaker at nearly 100 industry and ‘think-tank’ gatherings, including the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] (CSIS), Washington, D.C.; MIT; [[Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies]] (SAIS), Washington, D.C.; Stanford University; Texas A&M University; [[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]] (CERA); King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals; U.S. Department of Energy, Washington, D.C. and American Petroleum Institute, Washington, D.C. Saleri and his brother Alen J. Salerian published papers in the non-[[peer review]]ed ''[[Medical Hypotheses]]'' in 2005, 2007 and 2008.{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2005.07.021 |pmid=16326025 |title=Cooler biologically compatible core body temperatures may prolong longevity and combat neurodegenerative disorders |journal=Medical Hypotheses |volume=66 |issue=3 |pages=636–642 |year=2006 |last1=Salerian |first1=Alen J. |last2=Saleri |first2=Nansen G. }}{{PubMedAuthorSearch|Saleri|NG}}{{cite news| author =| title =JFK celebrated with a Magnificent Exhibition at the Woman’s National Democratic Club| quote =| newspaper = SwedishScene| date =November 2009| url =http://www.swedishscene.com/2009/11/jfk-celebrated-at-art-opening.html | accessdate =February 5, 2015}}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2007.06.032 |pmid=17951014 |title=Brain temperature may influence mood: A hypothesis |journal=Medical Hypotheses |volume=70 |issue=3 |pages=497–500 |year=2008 |last1=Salerian |first1=Alen J. |last2=Saleri |first2=Nansen G. |last3=Salerian |first3=Justin A. }}{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.mehy.2005.07.021 |pmid=16326025 |title=Cooler biologically compatible core body temperatures may prolong longevity and combat neurodegenerative disorders |journal=Medical Hypotheses |volume=66 |issue=3 |pages=636–642 |year=2006 |last1=Salerian |first1=Alen J. |last2=Saleri |first2=Nansen G. }}{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.b1963 |pmid=19482870 |pmc=3230235 |title=How do psychiatric drugs work? |journal=BMJ |volume=338 |pages=b1963 |year=2009 |last1=Moncrieff |first1=J. |last2=Cohen |first2=D. }} He is a Member of the Advisory Board of Petroleum Engineering at the [[University of Houston]] and has been a [[Society of Petroleum Engineers]] (SPE) Distinguished Lecturer and Journal of Petroleum Technology (JPT) Distinguished Author; Co-Chairman of the SPE European Forum; Keynote Speaker at the Fifth, Sixth and Eighth International Forums on Reservoir Simulation (1994, 2001 and 2005); SPE Speakers Bureau Member (1994–1997); Member of SPE Fluid Mechanics Committee (1996 to 1998). Saleri founded the Kristin Saleri Art Foundation, named after his mother, in 2011.{{cite news| author =Paulina Rojas| title =Family prepares to honor mother’s art| quote =| newspaper =[[The Daily Cougar]]| date = April 15, 2013| url =http://thedailycougar.com/2013/04/15/family-prepares-to-honor-mothers-art/| accessdate =February 5, 2015}} ===Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE) Journal Entries=== * Dr. Nansen G. Saleri (& others), ''Shaybah-220: A Maximum-Reservoir-Contact (MRC) Well and Its Implications for Developing Tight-Facies Reservoirs'' Volume 7, Number 4 August 2004 SPE 88986-PA * Dr. Nansen G. Saleri (& others), ''The Expanding Role of the Drill Bit in Shaping the Subsurface'' Volume 55, Number 12 December 2003 SPE 84923-MS * Dr. Nansen G. Saleri, ''“Learning” Reservoirs: Adapting to Disruptive Technologies'' Volume 54, Number 3 March 2002 SPE 73695-MS * Dr. Nansen G. Saleri, ''Reengineering Simulation: A Bottom-Line Approach to Managing Complexity and Complexification'' 1996 SPE 36696-MS * Dr. Nansen G. Saleri, ''Reservoir Performance Forecasting: Acceleration by Parallel Planning'' 1993 SPE 25151-PA ===Honors and awards=== He received the 2006 [[SPE John Franklin Carll Award]], given annually by the [[Society of Petroleum Engineers]] (SPE), for his outstanding contributions to modern reservoir management. ==Personal life== Nansen and his wife Marina live in Texas.{{cite news| author = | title = Petroleum Industry Awards Nansen Saleri, RA 66, for Work on Global Reserves (page 10)| quote =Saleri attended [[Robert Academy]] (1961-1966) and then Robert College (1966-1970), where he received his B.S. in Chemical Engineering. In 1970, he married his wife Marina, and the couple headed to the USA where pursued M.S. and PhD degrees at the University of Virginia.| newspaper =Robert College Alumni Magazine| date =2007| url =http://webportal.robcol.k12.tr/Alumni-Development/RC-quarterly/RC%20Quarterly/RCQ031.pdf| accessdate =February 5, 2015}}{{cite news| author =Saudi Aramco News| title =Reservoir Management Leader Saleri Says Farewell| quote =| newspaper =aramcoexpats.com| date =29 September 2007| url =http://www.aramcoexpats.com/articles/2007/09/reservoir-management-leader-saleri-says-farewell/| accessdate =February 5, 2015| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150206035511/http://www.aramcoexpats.com/articles/2007/09/reservoir-management-leader-saleri-says-farewell/| archivedate =6 February 2015| df =}}{{cite news| author =| title =Party Arty!| quote =| newspaper = HOUSTON Modern Luxury| date =| url =http://sanfrancisco.modernluxury.com/houston/scene/party-arty-8/img106997| accessdate =February 5, 2015}}{{cite news| author =Nansen G. Saleri, Quantum Reservoir Impact| title =Energy and Oil—A Personal Journey| quote =| newspaper =[[Society of Petroleum Engineers]]| date =2009| url = http://www.spe.org/twa/print/archives/2009/2009v5n3/10TWAv5n3_Academia.pdf| accessdate =February 5, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.energytribune.com/articles.cfm?aid=627 Dawn in the Desert - Saudi High Tech Paying Off at Ghawar Oil Field] ''Dawn in the Desert'' Energy Tribune by Dr. Nansen G. Saleri, September. 2007.{{dead link|date=February 2015}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FCg6wPdGnno Nansen Saleri Acceptance Speech for the John Franklin Carll Award] ''Nansen Saleri Acceptance Speech for the John Franklin Carll Award'' YouTube * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080325053631/http://www.csis.org/component/option,com_csis_events/task,view/id,429 Future of Global Oil Supply: Saudi Arabia] ''Future of Global Oil Supply: Saudi Arabia'' Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) with [[Matthew Simmons]], Mahmoud Abdul-Baqi, and Nansen Saleri.{{dead link|date=February 2015}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080325053631/http://www.csis.org/component/option,com_csis_events/task,view/id,429 Interview with Dr. Nansen Saleri, Mgr., Reservoir Management, SAUDI ARAMCO] ''Interview with Dr. Nansen Saleri, Mgr., Reservoir Management, SAUDI ARAMCO'' Cambridge Energy Research Associates, Inc. (CERA){{dead link|date=February 2015}} * [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120459389654809159 Wall Street Journal - Opinion: The World Has Plenty of Oil by Nansen G. Saleri] {{subscription required|s}} ==External links== * [http://www.qrigroup.com/nansen-saleri QRI Group, Nansen G. Saleri] {{DEFAULTSORT:Saleri, Nansen}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Armenian descent]] [[Category:Turkish Armenians]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:Sustainability advocates]] [[Category:University of Virginia School of Engineering and Applied Science alumni]] [[Category:People from Houston]] [[Category:People associated with energy]] [[Category:Boğaziçi University alumni]] [[Category:Robert College alumni]] [[Category:1947 births]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{multiple issues| {{More footnotes| article |date=February 2008}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2008}} }}
'''Nola Therese Fraser''' ([[married and maiden names|née]] '''Chalhoub''') is an Australian small business owner, former nurse and former [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] candidate on two occasions for the seat of [[Electoral district of Macquarie Fields|Macquarie Fields]]. Fraser became a [[whistleblower]] at two Sydney hospitals.
== Whistleblower ==
Fraser rose to prominence when she publicly criticised the administration of [[Camden, New South Wales|Camden]] and [[Campbelltown, New South Wales|Campbelltown]] hospitals in south-western [[Sydney]]. Her claims were backed by fellow nurses Valerie Owen, Vanessa Brag, Sheree Martin and Yvonne Quinn. On 5 November 2002, Fraser took her concerns to the health minister, and her local member of parliament, [[Craig Knowles]]. Fraser claimed that upon cataloguing the dangers patients faced at the hospitals, the minister threatened her.
Knowles demanded evidence, which the nurses provided, but after three weeks there had been no word on any investigation. It was reported that [[New South Wales Department of Health]] officials had been destroying incriminating documents. Meanwhile, an internal review concluded that the nurses' claims merited investigation by the [[Health Care Complaints Commission]].
On 25 February 2003, the HCCC recommended that no action be taken, having made "no findings that support any loss of confidence by the community in the Macarthur Health Service." The findings came three weeks before [[New South Wales state election, 2003|2003 state election]], which Labor won.
Fraser and her colleagues brought public attention to this matter with the help of [[talkback radio]] host [[Alan Jones (radio broadcaster)|Alan Jones]]. As HCCC investigations continued, according to a 2003 ''Sydney Morning Herald'' report, "those staff who were considering reporting their concerns about the failures watched helplessly as the whistleblower nurses were sidelined and victimised, their jobs placed in limbo." The department ordered a second investigation, led by the head of the [[Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care]]. A copy of the HCCC's interim report was leaked to the ''Sun-Herald''. The HCCC had concluded that of 47 complaints, at least 17 patients "had died after receiving unsafe, inadequate or questionable care" at Camden and Campbelltown. But the report did not lay blame with any individual. In response, the opposition [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] led by [[John Brogden (politician)|John Brogden]] took up the nurses' concerns, decrying what they described as a "cover-up".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/12/12/1071125658578.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Exposing a tragic mess | date=13 December 2003}}</ref>
An [[Independent Commission Against Corruption (New South Wales)|Independent Commission Against Corruption]] inquiry into Knowles' behaviour cleared the minister in September 2005.<ref name=icac-findings>{{cite press release | title =ICAC makes no findings of corrupt conduct in relation to the Hon. Craig Knowles MP | publisher =Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) | date= 13 April 2005 | url =http://www.icac.nsw.gov.au/media-centre/media-releases/article/2600 | accessdate =2 May 2014}}</ref>
== Political campaigns ==
After Knowles resigned from Parliament in 2005, Fraser contested his seat of [[Electoral district of Macquarie Fields|Macquarie Fields]] for the [[Liberal Party of Australia]]. Fraser achieved a swing of 12% for her party, not enough to defeat Labor's [[Steven Chaytor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.nsw.gov.au/state_government_elections/election_results/district_index/macquarie_fields/results/2005_byelection|title=2005 Macquarie Fields By-Election Results |date=22 September 2005|publisher=[[New South Wales Electoral Commission]]|accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref>
Fraser was again endorsed by the Liberals for the [[New South Wales state election, 2007|March 2007 election]]. However, Fraser was unable to improve on her by-election result and was defeated by Labor's candidate, Dr [[Andrew McDonald (Australian politician)|Andrew McDonald]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elections.nsw.gov.au/state_government_elections/electoral_districts/all_districts_/macquarie_fields/results_2007/perferential_count |title=2007 State Election Results|date=3 January 2008|publisher=[[New South Wales Electoral Commission]]|accessdate=2008-12-03}}</ref>
Fraser again stood for Macquarie Fields at the [[New South Wales state election, 2011]] but this time as an independent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://macarthur-chronicle-camden.whereilive.com.au/news/story/nsw-election-2011-macquarie-fields-candidates/|title=NSW Election 2011: Macquarie Fields candidates|date=19 March 2011|work=Macarthur Chronicle|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> She gained approximately 11% of the primary votes.<ref>http://www.abc.net.au/elections/nsw/2011/guide/macq.htm</ref> The Liberal candidate Sam Eskaros won 37% of the primary vote but despite a heavy swing against him the sitting ALP member Andrew McDonald retained the seat with 51.5% of the two party preferred vote.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}}
== See also == * [[New South Wales state election, 2007]] * [[Sydney South West Area Health Service]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Semih Terzi''' (?-15 July 2016) was an officer in the [[Turkish Army]], who was shot dead while trying to capture the headquarters of the Special Forces Command during the 2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt together with other plotters.
==Military career== Terzi graduated from the [[Turkish Military Academy|Turkish Army Academy]] in 1989. In 2009, he was promoted to the rank of a [[Colonel commandant|Staff Colonel]] of the Engineer Corps ({{lang-tr|İstihkam Kurmay Albay}}). His promotion to the rank of a [[Brigadier general#Turkey|Brigadier general]] (''Tuğgeneral'') by the [[Supreme Military Council (Turkey)|Supreme Military Council]] took place in August 2014.<ref name="akit"/><ref name="bg1"/>
His last duty was commander of the 1st Special Forces Brigade and Special Forces Operations Base stationed in [[Silopi]], [[Şırnak]], southeastern Turkey.<ref name="bg1"/>
==On the night of the 2016 coup d'état attempt== On 15 July 2016, a group of military attempted a [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]. Within the frame of the military actions, a group of coup plotters tried to capture the commander of the [[Special Forces Command (Turkey)|Special Forces]] [[Major general#Turkey|Maj. Gen.]] [[Zekai Aksakallı]]. He learned the coup plotters' intention, and was able to escape his followers. As he became aware of the plans of Brig. Gen. Semih Terzi to go [[Ankara]] in order to capture the headquarters of the Special Forces Command in [[Gölbaşı, Ankara|Gölbaşı]], he ordered Terzi around 00:30 hours local time by radio not to join the coup plotters. As Terzi showed signs of disobey, Aksakallı ordered the commander of the 3rd Special Forces commander Brig. Gen. Halil Soysal, who was stationed at Saladin town in Northern Iraq, to go to Silopi and to take over command there in order to neutralize the insurgent personnel by eventually interning the duty officer Col. Celal Koca.<ref name="bg1"/>
In the meantime, Terzi was underway from [[Diyarbakır Air Base]] to [[Akınci Air Base]] in Ankara by an aircraft. From there, he and twenty officers of diverse ranks flew by helicopter to Gölbaşı. The capture of the headquarters of Special Forces Command was very important for the coup plotters because they would be able to counteract any attempt of the government to prevent the coup, to commit suicides or rescue operations by controlling all the special units. After neutralizing the guards at the main entrance, they entered the headquarters front yard around 02:30 hours. Terzi notified the duty officer of the headquarters that he takes control of the Special Forces. At that moment, Terzi was shot dead by [[Sergeant major|Sgt. Maj.]] [[Ömer Halisdemir]], who was instructed by Gen. Maj. Zekai Aksakallı and was loyal to him. The putschist soldiers accompanying Terzi immediately killed Halisdemir in response.<ref name="HT"/><ref name="scf"/> Terzi's body was wrapped in a cloth, and was rushed by helicopter to GATA Gülhane Military Medical Academy Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.<ref name="Yenicag"/> Halisdemir's body remained in the front yard of the headquarters. The death of Terzi prevented a change in the chain of command.<ref name="akit"/><ref name="scf"/>
==Burial== The body of Terzi was transferred to [[Erzincan]] for burial. However, the Erzincan Municipality, responsible for burial service, called him a "traitor", and rejected his burial in the city cemetery. His family, therefore, buried him in the back yard of their home.<ref name="akit"/>
==Family== He was survived by his wife Nazire Terzi.<ref name="Aydinlik"/> The widow was accused of "aiding the crime of violation of the constitution,", and was sentenced to 18 years in prison in February 2018 after having been detained 559 days in jail.<ref name="scf"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="akit">{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title=Semih Terzi |url=https://www.yeniakit.com.tr/kimdir/Semih_Terzi |work= |agency=[[Yeni Akit]] |location= |access-date=21 April 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="Yenicag">{{cite news |last= |first= |date=7 August 2017 |title=Darbeci Semih Terzi'nin son mesajları ortaya çıktı Kaynak Yeniçağ: Darbeci Semih Terzi'nin son mesajları ortaya çıktı|url=http://www.yenicaggazetesi.com.tr/darbeci-semih-terzinin-son-mesajlari-ortaya-cikti-169972h.htm |work= |agency=[[Yeniçağ]] |location= |access-date=21 April 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="HT">{{cite news |last= |first= |date=20 February 2017 |title=Semih Terzi kimdir? |url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/1397871-semih-terzi-kimdir |work= |location= |agency=[[Habertürk]] |access-date=21 April 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="Aydinlik">{{cite news |last= |first= |date=7 August 2017 |title=Darbeci Semih Terzi'nin son mesajları ortaya çıktı |url=https://www.aydinlik.com.tr/darbeci-semih-terzi-nin-son-mesajlari-ortaya-cikti-turkiye-agustos-2017|agency=[[Aydınlık]] |work= |location= |access-date=22 April 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="bg1">{{cite news |url=http://beyazgazete.com/haber/2018/2/27/15-temmuz-da-silopi-deki-askeri-uste-yasananlara-iliskin-dava-4352702.html |newspaper=Beyaz Gazete |title=15 Temmuz'da Silopi'deki Askeri Üste Yaşananlara İlişkin Dava |date=2018-02-27 |language=tr |accessdate=2018-04-22 }}</ref> <ref name="scf">{{cite news |url=https://stockholmcf.org/widow-of-slain-turkish-general-says-july-15-shrouded-in-mystery-facts-should-come-out/ |newspaper=Stockholm Center for Freedom |title=Widow of slain Turkish general says July 15 shrouded in mystery, facts should come out |date=2018-02-13 |accessdate=2018-04-22 }}</ref> }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Terzi, Semih}} [[Category:Date of birth missing]] [[Category:People from Erzincan]] [[Category:Turkish Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Turkish Army generals]] [[Category:People involved in the 2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Turkey]] [[Category:2016 deaths]]

Assistant |status=Injured reserve |highlights= * All-GNAC (2008) * 3× [[ArenaBowl]] champion ([[ArenaBowl XXIII|XXIII]], [[ArenaBowl XXIX|XXIX]], [[ArenaBowl XXX|XXX]]) * [[ArenaBowl]] MVP ([[ArenaBowl XXIX|XXIX]]) * Second Team [[All-Arena]] ([[2017 Arena Football League season#All-Arena team|2017]]) * CAFL All-Pro South Division All-Star ({{CAFL Year|2016}}) |aflstatseason= |aflstatlabel1=Receptions |aflstatvalue1=519 |aflstatlabel2=Receiving yards |aflstatvalue2=6,520 |aflstatlabel3=Receiving TDs |aflstatvalue3=130 |aflstatlabel4=Return yards |aflstatvalue4=683 |afl=11304 }} '''Shaun Kauleinamoku''' (born May 24, 1987) is an [[arena football]] [[wide receiver]] for the [[Philadelphia Soul]] of the [[Arena Football League]] (AFL). He played collegiately at [[Western Oregon University]]. Kauleinamoku has also been member of the [[Spokane Shock]], [[San Antonio Talons]], [[Utah Blaze]], [[Pittsburgh Power]] and [[Shanghai Skywalkers]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ksl.com/?sid=20586090 |title=Turnovers costly for Blaze in loss to Talons |date=May 27, 2012 |publisher=KSL Broadcasting |work=www.ksl.com |accessdate=May 15, 2014}} ==Professional career== ===Philadelphia Soul=== On January 26, 2015, Kauleinamoku was assigned to the [[Philadelphia Soul]].{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=4920147 |title=Shaun Kauleinamoku Joins Philadelphia Soul |date=January 26, 2015 |publisher=OurSports Central |work=www.oursportscentral.com |accessdate=January 27, 2015}} On January 26, 2016, Kauleinamoku was assigned to the Soul for the 2016 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/from-hawaii-to-philly/n-5153189 |title=From Hawaii to Philly |date=June 1, 2016 |publisher=OurSports Central |work=www.oursportscentral.com |accessdate=June 2, 2016}} On August 26, 2016, the Soul beat the [[Arizona Rattlers]] in [[ArenaBowl XXIX]] by a score of 56–42 and Kauleinamoku was named ArenaBowl MVP.{{cite web|url=http://www.arenafootball.com/sports/a-footbl/spec-rel/082616aaq.html |title=Soul Defeat Rattlers, 56-42, to Claim AFL Crown |publisher=arenafootball.com |date=August 26, 2016 |accessdate=August 28, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160828165845/http://www.arenafootball.com/sports/a-footbl/spec-rel/082616aaq.html |archivedate=August 28, 2016 |df= }} He earned Second Team [[All-Arena]] honors in 2017.{{cite web | url=http://www.arenafootball.com/articles/afl-announces-all-arena-first-and-second-teams | title=AFL Announces All-Arena First and Second Teams | publisher=arenafootball.com | date=August 21, 2017 | accessdate=September 15, 2017 | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170916034752/http://www.arenafootball.com/articles/afl-announces-all-arena-first-and-second-teams | archivedate=September 16, 2017 | df= }} On August 26, 2017, the Soul beat the [[Tampa Bay Storm]] in [[ArenaBowl XXX]] by a score of 44–40.{{cite web | url=http://www.arenafootball.com/articles/soul-snare-second-straight-foster-trophy-in-arenabowl-xxx | title=Soul Snare Second Straight Foster Trophy in ArenaBowl XXX | publisher=arenafootball.com | accessdate=August 27, 2017 | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827235503/http://www.arenafootball.com/articles/soul-snare-second-straight-foster-trophy-in-arenabowl-xxx | archivedate=August 27, 2017 | df= }} ===Shanghai Skywalkers=== Kauleinamoku was drafted by the [[Shanghai Skywalkers]] in the fourth round of the [[2016 CAFL Draft]].{{cite web | url=http://caflfootball.com/cafl-draft-results-are-in/ | title=CAFL DRAFT RESULTS – SEE IT AGAIN – FULL RESULTS HERE | publisher=caflfootball.com | date=June 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 18, 2016}} He earned All-Pro South Division All-Star honors after catching 37 passes for 479 yards and 16 touchdowns.{{cite web | url=http://caflfootball.com/series-final-one-for-the-record-books/ | title=Series Final: One for the Record Books | publisher=caflfootball.com | date=November 6, 2016 | accessdate=July 22, 2017 | author=Moninghoff, Mick}}{{cite web|url=http://caflfootball.com/the-cafl-has-announced-their-2016-all-pro-south-division-all-stars/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107023136/http://caflfootball.com/the-cafl-has-announced-their-2016-all-pro-south-division-all-stars/ |archivedate=November 7, 2016 |title=The CAFL has announced their 2016 All-Pro South Division All-Stars |publisher=caflfootball.com |date=November 4, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016 |deadurl=yes }} He also rushed for 71 yards and 4 touchdowns. He is listed on the Skywalkers' roster for the [[2018 CAFL season|2018 season]].{{cite web | url=http://caflfootball.com/shanghai-skywalkers-2017-roster/ | title=Shanghai Skywalkers 2017 Roster | publisher=caflfootball.com | date=August 14, 2017 | accessdate=September 29, 2017 | deadurl=bot: unknown | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929183925/http://caflfootball.com/shanghai-skywalkers-2017-roster/ | archivedate=September 29, 2017 | df= }} ===AFL statistics=== {| class="wikitable {{Infobox Politician (general) |image = |imagesize = | name = Stephen W. Doran | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|3|26}} | birth_place = [[Boston]] | death_date = | death_place = |restingplace = | nationality = American | website = | occupation = State legislator
Parking lot manager
Bank executive
Tutor
Drug trafficker | residence = [[Dorchester, Boston|Dorchester]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = | alma_mater = [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] | title = Member of the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] from the 15th Middlesex district | term_start = 1981 | term_end = 1995 | predecessor = [[Lincoln P. Cole]] | successor = [[Jay R. Kaufman]] }} '''Stephen W. Doran''' is an American politician who was a member of the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] from 1981 to 1995. He later worked as a bank executive and math tutor. In 2014 he pleaded guilty to drug trafficking and is serving 3 years in prison; he is scheduled to finish his sentence in 2017. ==Early life== Doran was born on March 26, 1956, in [[Boston]]. He attended [[Lexington High School (Massachusetts)|Lexington High School]], the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]], and the [[London School of Economics]].{{cite book|title=Public Officers of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts 1992–1993|page=120|url=https://archive.org/stream/publicofficersof19931994bost#page/120/mode/2up}} ==Political career== Doran began his political career as a [[Lexington, Massachusetts|Lexington]] Town Meeting Member in 1975. In 1978 he unsuccessfully challenged incumbent state representative [[Lincoln P. Cole]]. In 1980 he defeated Cole to become the representative for the 15th Middlesex District.{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Laurence|title=No coattails for Mass. GOP|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=November 5, 1980}} During his freshman term, Doran was an active participant in the House budget debate.{{cite news|last=Black|first=Chris|title=The House's independent freshmen|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=June 11, 1981}} At the beginning of his second term, Doran was a leader of a bipartisan coalition of more than fifty representatives who sought to reform the House rules. Their proposed changes included limiting sessions to the hours between 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., requiring that agendas be published for all formal sessions, that all conference reports be distributed 24 hours before floor action, and allowing television and radio journalists to broadcast formal House sessions.{{cite news|title=House Group Hopes to Win Rules Changes|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 5, 1983}}{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Laurence|title=House Moves to Lift TV Ban|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 11, 1983}} He also was a leading supporter of overhauling the prevailing-wage law, which required the Commonwealth and municipal governments to pay union wages on contractual jobs, such as construction or snow removal.{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Laurence|title=9 Union Leaders Back McGee Over Keverian|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=July 19, 1984}} While serving in the House, Doran had a parking lot concession in [[Cape Cod]] and spent most of the summer running it.{{cite news|title=Short Circuit|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=July 1, 1984}} ===Ethics Committee=== In 1989, Speaker [[George Keverian]] chose Doran to chair the House Ethics Committee.{{cite news|last=Loth|first=Renee|title=House Leadership Team Includes No Minorities|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 18, 1989}} In 1990, the committee chose to take no action against Keverian after he admitted to hiring subordinates to do remodeling work on his house and accepting free rugs from a legislative vendor. The committee concluded that the conflict of interest law Keverian admitted to violating does not exist in the House ethics code and therefore took no disciplinary action against him.{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Frank|title=House Ethics Panel Urges No Action Against Keverian|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=May 9, 1990}} In 1991, the committee voted 6 to 5 to remove [[Kevin Fitzgerald (American politician)|Kevin Fitzgerald]] from his position as majority whip for having accepted a $200,000 inheritance from a troubled homeless woman. Doran sided with two other Democrats and three Republicans in favor of sanctioning Fitzgerald.{{cite news|last=McGrory|first=Brian|title=For Fitzgerald, a fast rise, a long fall|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=December 22, 1991}} In 1994, the committee was on the verge of recommending the expulsion of representative [[John McNeil (American politician)|John McNeil]] due to charges that he solicited sex from one of his former interns. However, [[Massachusetts Attorney General]] [[Scott Harshbarger]] and US Attorney [[John Pappalardo]] requested that the committee suspend its work due to fears that taking testimony from witnesses during a quasijudicial hearing could jeopardize their cases (which included extortion, bribery, money laundering, and mail fraud) against McNeil.{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Frank|title=`Reluctantly,' panel halts McNeil probe|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=October 1, 1992}} ==Post-political career== In 1994, Doran chose not to run for reelection and instead entered the banking industry as a vice president at Fleet Mortgage, a subsidiary of [[FleetBoston Financial|Fleet Financial Group]].{{cite news|last=Iudica|first=Doreen|title=Hopkinton woman launches bid to bump Magnani from Senate|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=March 13, 1994}}{{cite news|last=Cassidy|first=Tina|title=Government shutdown backs up mortgages|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 13, 1996}} At Fleet, Doran oversaw the company's New England mortgage operations.{{cite news|last=Collins|first=James|title=Mortgage Rates Rise to 1-Year High, Adjustable Loans Drawing Attention|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=August 8, 2003}} In August 2012, Doran began working as a math tutor at MATCH Public Charter Middle School in [[Jamaica Plain]]. He was later diagnosed with stage three melanoma and began chemotherapy. ===Methamphetamine trafficking=== On May 21, 2013, Doran received a package at the school. State Police, acting on a tip, detained Doran on the street and obtained the package from the school front desk. The package contained two heat-sealed baggies containing 480 grams of [[Methamphetamine|crystal meth]]. Authorities then obtained a warrant to search Doran's home. There they found an additional 38 grams of meth, about $10,000 in cash, and a digital scale and other items consistent with drug distribution. He was arrested on charges of trafficking methamphetamine and violating the state's law against drug in a school zone. The drugs had a street value of about $50,000{{cite news|title=Police: Tutor received package containing meth at charter school|url=http://www.myfoxboston.com/story/22393659/2013/05/22/police-tutor-received-package-containing-meth-at-charter-school|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=myfoxboston.com|date=May 22, 2013}}{{cite news|title=The real-life Breaking Bad? School teacher with cancer arrested for drug trafficking after he his found with two bags of meth|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2330138/The-real-life-Breaking-Bad-School-teacher-cancer-arrested-drug-trafficking-bag-meth.html|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=May 24, 2013}} On March 31, 2014, Doran pleaded guilty to trafficking in methamphetamine and money laundering. He was sentenced to three years in prison followed by two years of probation. According to one of his defense attorneys, Doran was a "terrible addict" who had sought treatment and been substance-free since his arrest.{{cite news|title=Ex-pol cops plea in case evoking ''Breaking Bad''|url=http://bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2014/03/ex_pol_cops_plea_in_case_evoking_breaking_bad|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=April 1, 2014}} Due to the similarities, Doran's case has been compared to the television show ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' and Doran has been compared to its protagonist, [[Walter White (Breaking Bad)|Walter White]].{{cite news|title=Real-Life Walter White? Stephen Doran, Massachusetts Tutor With Cancer, Charged With Trafficking Meth|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/24/real-life-walter-white-stephen-doran_n_3333152.html|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=May 24, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Real-life 'Walter White' arrested in Mass. : teacher battling cancer was 'trafficking meth'|url=https://nypost.com/2013/05/23/real-life-walter-white-arrested-in-mass-teacher-battling-cancer-was-trafficking-meth/|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=New York Post|date=May 23, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Ryan|first=Patrick|title=Real-life crimes echo 'Breaking Bad'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/09/19/breaking-bad-real-life-crimes/2782635/|accessdate=April 3, 2014|newspaper=USA Today|date=September 19, 2013}} Like White, Doran was a teacher who began dealing crystal meth after being diagnosed with cancer. Both men also underwent chemotherapy and are bald as a result. ==References== {{reflist|25em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doran, Stephen W.}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:American business executives]] [[Category:American drug traffickers]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Boston]] [[Category:Educators from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Massachusetts Democrats]] [[Category:Members of the Massachusetts House of Representatives]] [[Category:Politicians from Boston]] [[Category:People from Lexington, Massachusetts]] [[Category:People with cancer]] [[Category:University of Massachusetts Amherst alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:Lexington High School alumni]]

'''Thai names''' are comparable to the Western European pattern in which the [[family name]] follows a first or [[given name]]. In this, they differ from the family-name-first pattern of the general [[East Asia]]n tradition.
Thai names (given and family) are often long, and there are a great many of them. The diversity of family names is because they are required to be unique to a family, and they are a recent introduction. Also, a number of Thai people change their given names relatively frequently (and their family names less frequently, as it requires permission of the head of a family or, in the case of children, father and mother). This practice is virtually unknown in most other countries outside of marriage and [[fortune-telling]] traditions. Besides standard reasons of separation and divorce, many name changes are done to get rid of bad luck (which, if caused by a ghost or spirit, would confuse the malignant entity, allowing the victim to get free from them).
Last names became legally required of Thai citizens in 1913.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Baker|first1=Christopher J.|last2=Phongpaichit|first2=Pasuk|title=A History of Thailand|date=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=978-0-521-767-682 |page=97|pages=|edition=2nd}}</ref> Before then, most Thais used only a first or individual name. The names generally convey positive attributes. Under Thai law, only one family can use any given surname: Thus, any two people of the same surname must be related.{{cn|date=May 2014}}
Thai surnames are often long, particularly among [[Thai Chinese|Thais of Chinese descent]]. For example, the family of former Prime Minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]], who is of Chinese descent, adopted the name Shinawatra ("does good routinely") in 1938. According to the current law, Person Name Act, [[Thai solar calendar|BE]] 2505 (1962), to create a new Thai surname, it must not be longer than ten [[Thai alphabet|Thai letter]]s, excluding vowel symbols and diacritics.<ref name="Nittaya-Royin-1">{{cite web|url=http://www.royin.go.th/th/knowledge/detail.php?ID=1929|date=|accessdate=2014-12-28|script-title=th:เรื่องของนามสกุล (๑)|author=รศ. ดร.นิตยา กาญจนะวรรณ|publisher=[[Royal Institute of Thailand]]|language=th|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228112902/http://www.royin.go.th/th/knowledge/detail.php?ID=1929|archivedate=2014-12-28|df=}}</ref> The same law also forbids the creation of a surname that duplicated any existing surnames, There are some duplicates dating to the time before computer databases were available to prevent this.<ref name="Nittaya-Royin-2">{{cite web|url=http://www.royin.go.th/th/knowledge/detail.php?ID=1928|date=|accessdate=2014-12-28|script-title=th:เรื่องของนามสกุล (๒)|author=รศ. ดร.นิตยา กาญจนะวรรณ|publisher=[[Royal Institute of Thailand]]|language=th|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228112833/http://www.royin.go.th/th/knowledge/detail.php?ID=1928|archivedate=2014-12-28|df=}}</ref> Some creations added the name of their location ([[muban]], [[tambon]] or [[amphoe]]) into surnames, similar to [[Family name affixes|family name suffixes]].<ref name="Korat-surnamesuffixes1">{{cite web | url= http://www.encyclopediathai.org/thaihis/namekorat.htm |date=1995 | accessdate=2014-12-28|script-title=th:นามสกุลชาวโคราช |trans-title=Surnames of Korat people |author=สุวรรณ ทำเสมอดี |publisher= |quote=ในจังหวัดนครราชสีมาหรือโคราชนั้น นิยมตั้งนามสกุลตามภูมิลำเนาที่เกิด หรืออยู่อาศัย ใช้ชื่อตำบล อำเภอ และหมู่บ้านเป็นส่วนท้ายของนามสกุล |language=th}}</ref><ref name="Non_Sung-surnamesuffixes1">{{cite web | url= http://province.m-culture.go.th/nakhonratchasima/data/data_amphur/nonsong.doc |date=| accessdate=2014-12-28|title= อำเภอโนนสูง |trans-title=Non Sung District|quote=ชาวอำเภอโนนสูง ส่วนใหญ่ จะมีนามสกุล ลงท้ายด้วยคำว่า "กลาง" ซึ่งเป็นชื่อเดิมของอำเภอ เป็นส่วนใหญ่ ซึ่งเป็นเอกลักษณ์ของชาวอำเภอโนนสูง เช่นเดียวกับอำเภออื่น ๆ ในจังหวัดนครราชสีมา ที่นิยมลงท้ายนามสกุลด้วยชื่ออำเภอ|author= |publisher=[[Ministry of Culture (Thailand)]] }}{{DOClink}}{{th icon}}</ref><ref name="Thaisong-surnamesuffix">{{cite web |url=http://phutthaisongmncp.go.th/?name=page&file=index&id=136 |title=ต้นตระกูลไธสง |accessdate=2014-12-28 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201143803/http://phutthaisongmncp.go.th/?name=page&file=index&id=136 |archivedate=December 1, 2014 |df= }} {{Th icon}}</ref>
As a measure of the diversity of Thai names, in a sample of 45,665 names, 81% of family names were unique, and 35% of given names were unique: The people with shared family names are related, and the diversity of given names is conventional.{{Dead link|date=April 2014}}<ref>[http://seasrc.th.net/pdf/xthname.pdf 45,665 Thai names: Examining passlist.96] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226203617/http://seasrc.th.net/pdf/xthname.pdf |date=2008-02-26 }}, by Doug Cooper</ref>
==Royal and feudal names== {{see also|Rama (Kings of Thailand)|List of Thai Monarchs|Thai royal and noble titles}} East Asian monarchs often adopted [[Regnal name#East_Asia|regnal names]] upon ascending the throne, as was done in [[Thailand]] until the present day. In addition, subjects of a monarch may be awarded both a title and a name, such as in the case of Sing (or [[Singh]]) Sinhaseni ({{lang|th|สิงห์ สิงหเสนี}}) who was awarded the title of [[Thai_royal_and_noble_titles#Chao_Phraya|Chao Phraya]] and the name of [[Bodindecha]] ({{lang-th|เจ้าพระยาบดินทรเดชา}}.)
Kings [[Rama I]] and [[Rama II of Siam|Rama II]] were awarded noble titles and names before they assumed regnal names, which were then changed by subsequent kings. As neither noble titles nor names are necessarily unique, it is customary to list the highest title and awarded named first, followed by former names and titles (and personal and family names in parentheses) as needed.
==Noble names== Descendants of the nobility, both hereditary and non-hereditary positions, generally take the [[Thai royal and noble titles#Descendants of a Sovereign|noble name]] of their ancestor for a surname. For instance, [[Hugo (musician)|Hugo Chakrabongse]] is a descendant of Prince [[Chakrabongse Bhuvanath]]. Some (far removed) descendants of royalty add the preposition and [[nobility particle]] "na" ([[wikt:ณ|ณ]]) to geographical names to create surnames, in the same way that members of German noble families use ''[[von]]''.
Thus [[Mongkol Na Songkhla]], a minister in the Surayud government, has a name indicating that he is a distant descendant of royalty or nobility in that geographical region (for instance, the surname "Na Chiangmai", belonging to descendants of the rulers of Chiang Mai, which was a vassal state of Siam). The name of [[Kasem Sanitwong Na Ayutthaya]], another minister, indicates that he is related to the royal family, as it is also tradition for far-removed descendants to add "[[Thai royal and noble titles#Na Ayutthaya|Na Ayutthaya]]" after their surnames. In this case, Sanitwong is the family name of Kasem. Sanitwong itself being a name of a royal consort of Rama V and the subsequent family name for her descendants.
==Formal names== Formal surnames were a 20th-century innovation of [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst|Sandhurst-educated]] King [[Vajiravudh#Education|Vajiravudh]] (Rama VI, r.1910 – 25).
The Council of Royal [[Pandit]]s, predecessor to the [[Royal Institute of Thailand#History|Royal Institute of Thailand]], was available to assist in deriving palace names, as they were called. For an example, see the [[Abhisit Vejjajiva#Background|background of the Vejjajiva]] palace name. The latter-day [[Royal Thai General System of Transcription]] would transcribe it as "Wetchachiwa". Formal personal names follow from traditional practice to include individual awards of palace-given names.
== Polite names == In [[manners|polite speech]], Thais address each or refer to each other by a given name, preceded by the [[Thai royal and noble titles#Khun (courtesy title)|courtesy title ''khun'']], particularly with persons of higher status or public distinction. Thus, the ministers mentioned above would be addressed and referred to as "Khun Mongkol" and "Khun Kasem". "Khun" pronounced with an even tone should not be confused with rising-tone [[Thai royal and noble titles#Khun|khun]], an obsolete feudal title, or ever replaced with "[[Thai_royal_and_noble_titles#Khunying|Khunying]]", comparable to formal [[Lady]] in Western culture, still sometimes awarded.
==Informal names== Informal names are awarded at birth and may continue in use to the extent one may have to check the formal registration to find a person's given formal name. Thais may address each other by [[nicknames]] ({{lang-th|ชื่อเล่น|translit=chue-len}}). Bestowed by relatives or playmates in early childhood, these are commonly one syllable (or worn down from two to one). These may often be nonsense words or humorous and seldom relate to the registered name except in cases where it is a [[diminutive]], such as "Nok" for "Noknoi," or ''bird'' from ''little bird''. All Thais have such names; they are freely used in everyday life. Some may have additional nicknames bestowed by friends or colleagues, especially during school or adolescence. Nicknames may link with a notable physical feature or behavior. In everyday life, a Thai is introduced by nickname and others may not know the person's formal name. When so introduced, one usually continues to use the nickname.
The evolution of Thai nicknames dates back to the [[Sukhothai Kingdom|Sukhothai era]], when names were used to mark the order of children. Nicknames such as "Ai", "Yee", and "Sam" designated children as "one", "two", and "three". Later, in the [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]] and [[Rattanakosin Kingdom|Rattanakosin]] periods, children began to be named for physical attributes, such as "Daeng" (red) or "Uan" (fat) or for desirable items such as "Thong" (gold). Conversely, unflattering nicknames such as "Mah (dog)", "Moo (pig)", or "Kob (frog)" were employed to keep malign spirits from coveting the child. [[King Mongkut]] (Rama IV) (1804-1868) stimulated interest in naming babies in accordance with astrological principles as outlined in the ancient scripture, ''Namtaksapakorn''.<ref name="KU-2013">{{cite journal|last1=Wongsantativanich|first1=Mingkwan|title=What’s in a Name?: An Analysis of English Nicknames of Thai People|journal=Humanities Journal|date=2013|volume=20|issue=Special Issue|pages=133-166|url=http://158.108.54.4/humanjournal/files/journalonline/journal56/2556-special.pdf|accessdate=2 November 2016|publisher=Kasetsart University|issn=0859-3485}}</ref>
During the time of Field Marshal [[Plaek Phibunsongkhram]] (1897-1964), gender-based naming was introduced. Names ending in "-sak", "-chai", and "-yot" were for male babies, "-porn" or "-sri" for females. In the 21st century, assigning nicknames still relies heavily on astrological beliefs but in keeping up with current naming fashions. Observers have noted such modern nicknames as "Porsche", "Mercedes", "Benz", "Man U", "Big Mac", "Internet", and "Google", among others.<ref name="BP-20161102">{{cite news|last1=Pongpipat|first1=Kaona|title=What's in a Name?|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/special-reports/1125065/whats-in-a-name-|accessdate=2 November 2016|work=Bangkok Post|date=2 November 2016}}</ref>
[[King Bhumibol Adulyadej]]'s nickname, for example, was Ong Lek ({{lang-th| องค์เล็ก}}; ''Ong'' is a numerative noun for kings, princes, princesses, priests, images of Buddha, gods, angels, palaces, pagodas; "lek" means "little (one)", a common name for younger siblings).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/1100369/introducing-fatty-piggy-and-mrs-frog|title=Introducing Fatty, Piggy and Mrs Frog|date=2 October 2016|work=Bangkok Post|format=Opinion|last1=Crutchley|first1=Roger|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> Former Prime Minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s nickname is {{lang-th|แม้ว|translit=Maew}}, Thai for the [[Miao people]]. By way of example preceding formal naming, [[Plaek Pibulsongkram#Early years|Plaek Pibulsongkram]]'s childhood name meant "strange". He later adopted as a surname what was originally an award for academic excellence and generally known in public life by the shortened form "Pibun." Thailand's first female Prime Minister, [[Yingluck Shinawatra]], is nicknamed ''Pu'' "crab" ({{lang|th|ปู}}; {{IPA-th|pūː }}).<ref>{{cite news |script-title=th:'ปู'ปัดบินฮ่องกงพบพี่ชาย ไม่รู้'สมศักดิ์'อยากร่วมรบ. |date=8 July 2011 |language=Thai |newspaper=Thairath |location=Bangkok |trans-title="'Pu' denied flying to Hong Kong to see her brother, not knowing Somsak's joining coalition"}}</ref>
==Indexing== According to the [[Chicago Manual of Style]], Thai names may be [[Subject indexing|indexed]] depending upon the individual practice. Often they may be alphabetized under the given name with no comma and no inversion, but they may also be alphabetized under the surname with a comma and with an inversion.<ref>"[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/CHIIndexingComplete.pdf Indexes: A Chapter from The Chicago Manual of Style]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6WQIXWdqH?url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/CHIIndexingComplete.pdf Archive]). [[Chicago Manual of Style]]. Retrieved on December 23, 2014. p. 28 (PDF document p. 30/56).</ref>
